types of doughs﻿
top_comment.author: Grace Ma

comments.text:
+Grace Ma that sounds like something was off Grace, how long did you let it 
rest? the dough shouldn't be that sticky after fermenting for a while.
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford The dough was far too sticky and tacky. Because I had to 
flour HEAVILY, there was quite some unnecessary flour so they came out 
crunchy on the outside. The middle was beautiful and the concept of this is 
brilliant nonetheless.
comments.author: Grace Ma

comments.text:
+Grace Ma  so to make yeasted doughs you need to develop gluten. You can 
use a machine to develop the gluten, like we normal do OR you can use time, 
which is what the 'no knead ' method does. Over time and the fermenting of 
the yeast that develops gluten. It is really a fantastic way to make 
doughs. And also you will notice they have much better flavor too because 
of the fermenting. Does this make sense? How did you rolls turn out?  :)

+Joely P dissolving the yeast will definitely help your yeast. This dough 
rises so big so definitely something is up if it doesn't rise at all. 
A different tray will help a lot. I notice the tray makes a huge difference 
to my end result. Don't buy expensive trays, got to TJMAXX and get great 
quality for very little money :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
I used active dry yeast and I will definitely dissolve it in warm water 
next time! I put the baking tray on the second last shelf of the oven. I'll 
try a different tray next time! I spend too much time watching 
cooking/baking videos. I love to try new things and always try to remember 
tips YouTubers give in their videos. :)
comments.author: Joely P

comments.text:
+Joely P That's great they tasted delicious, I agree they are like 
cinnabon. 
So what kind of yeast are you using? Fast active? or rapid rise? Definitely 
if it hand;r risen after 2 hours it dod not get dissolved. You might have 
to 'sponge' your yeast if this is happening. It is just a little extra 
step. Dissolve it in a little of the warm water.
The baking time is funny. I always bake in the center of the oven or 
higher, what shelf did you bake them on? and yeah always use a thick, good 
quality baking tray. I have learned my lesson using thin bad trays. 
I can tell by your questions that you are not an amateur bakers :), I hope 
this helps.

yeast flavor you are talking about is mostly from the actually natural 
fermenting of the dough. It is natural yeast that is created in these 
doughs so you will always get a bit of that in a no knead dough. In my 
recipe it really is a tiny bit of yeast. The flavor is a tiny boozy (what 
you are saying is yeasty) but it is good flavor, not bad. I do recommend 
you try it. I feel you will really like it. If you do, make a full recipe. 
I don't recommend to half this recipe, it doesn't like that :).Sound good?

+Jah-nette Smith Hi Janette. It is easy to distinguish them. "Dry yeast" 
can be found in supermarket, and often called "Levure de boulanger"

comments.author: Stève A

comments.text:
+Stève A That is really great you got fresh yeast. I have not been able to 
buy fresh yeast for ages. So with fresh yeast you have to dissolve it in 
warm liquid. Whatever the liquid you are using. Warm it, add a little bit 
of your sugar (or honey) and crumble it in. Then stir until dissolved. 
Cover with cling wrap and let it 'bloom' (come alive) for 10 minutes. You 
'should' come back and see it foam on top and look alive. then just add 
that into your recipe at the same time i add in the yeast. I hope this 
makes sense. Otherwise, buy fired yeast :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford I've found the fresh yeast in a bakery. They were a little 
bit suprised when I asked for it, but I got it for 20 cents (euro). And 
no... i did not used water : bad, all bad. I put in in the flour, just like 
you did, appart from the salt. Tonigh >> second try. I can't wait for 
tasting these exotic baking. Good night from France
comments.author: Stève A

comments.text:
+Stève A there you go, fresh yeast. It is less powerful and you have to use 
double the amount then dried. I love using fresh yeast but it is very hard 
to get for me. Next time use dried or double the amount of fresh yeast. Did 
you bloom the fresh yeast in liquid before adding it to the flour mix?

comments.text: Hahahaha I freaking love this kind of science! :) Thanks for explaining!
comments.author: Vicky Sanchez

comments.text:
+Vicky Sanchez so you make a very good point about the bubbles getting lost 
because of rolling. it took me a while to learn that rolling or 'knocking 
back' dough actually helps create even bigger and better bubbles. It 
strengthens the gluten structure of the bread to hold even more bubbles. 
When you don't know out the air the dough walls are 'weaker'. Science! 
Dough making shouldn't be difficult, thats why I love this method :), happy 
Baking :)

should be that the temperature of your oven is a bit too high. Lower the 
temperature a little bit and it should work better the next time.

captions.text: (Music)

Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking
No-Knead Cinnamon Rolls

Hi Bold Bakers! Today I'm sharing with you
my favorite method for making yeast doughs

and that is no-knead dough. And with this
dough, we are making BIG & BOLD cinnamon rolls.

I really think this is a great technique for
a lot of you because you do not need any machine.
Just time. So let's get baking!

So what is no-knead dough? Simply it is a
dough that does not require a machine. You

use time. Hours even days to develop the gluten
in the dough eliminating the need for a machine.

I'm going to explain it as we go through the
recipe.

So we're going to start out in a large bowl.
Use the largest bowl you have because we're
also going to proof our dough in this bowl.

In your bowl, put in your flour, salt, and
yeast. Don't let the yeast come in direct

contact with the salt so put them on separate
sides of the bowl. Once you mix it, it will be totally fine.

In a separate jug, add in your milk, water,
honey, and butter.

We're going to heat this in the microwave
gently until the butter melts.

You don't want to heat this mix too hot because
we're going to add in our eggs to it.
So whisk in your room temperature eggs.
And keep on whisking until they're all combined.

Now we're going to add our liquid to our dry
and we're going to mix it with a spatula until
there are no more lumps of flour left.

Run your spatula along the bottom of the bowl
to make sure there are no flowery lumps in the bottom.

This no need method is not just for cinnamon
rolls. You can make make loafs of bread. You

can make pizza dough. It's a really fantastic
technique.

And this is our cinnamon bun dough. It's that
easy. Isn't this so much better than using a machine?

Scrape down the sides of the bowl. We're going
to cover it in cling film, put a tea towel

on top, and let it proof at room temperature
for two hours.

So our dough has been proofing for two hours.
It is lovely and bubbly and nice and big.

We're going to put it in the fridge now for
overnight and this is where the magic happens.

So I made a cinnamon roll dough yesterday and this
is what it looks like.
It grows really big. It smells really boozy,

which is great because that's all flavor.
And it's lovely and bubbly.
This is going to make a beautiful dough.

And what I love about this, is that you can
actually leave it in the fridge for three

days in advance so you don't have to wake
up at the crack of dawn to make cinnamon rolls.
I'm going to set this dough aside for a minute

and we're going to make our smear for the
inside of the cinnamon rolls.

For your cinnamon filling, we're going to
melt the butter in a bowl.

Add in your brown sugar and your cinnamon.
Then mix these ingredients together. And that's
your filling for the inside.

Now it's time to roll out our dough and you're
going to see the advantages of letting it

proof overnight and what good it does to the
dough.
Just flour your surface
and then turn out your dough.
See all these beautiful strands of gluten,
these developed overnight with time

the same effect you'd get from actually using
a mixer.
So this is a much easier method.

When the dough rests, it gets stronger, it
grows.

All of the gasses build up. They create these
beautiful bubbles
and they also create really good flavor.

This actually might be hard to replicate on
a machine.

This is my favorite part when you get your
hands dirty and get to work with the dough.
And just start to roll out your dough.
Toss a little bit of flour on top.
And then roll lengthways.

When you're rolling out your dough, if you
see it springing back don't worry. It just

means the glutens need a little more time
to relax.

So let it sit there for maybe 3 minutes or
so
and it will be much easier to roll out.

Now that you've rolled out your dough, it's
time to lay on your smear.

Using a knife, spread your smear on the surface
of your dough

and just leave a little rim as not to go too
far to the edges.

I like to lay my smear on nice and thick because
a dry cinnamon roll is not what you're going for.
If you're gonna do it, do it BIG & BOLD!

On top of your smear, you can actually add
raisins

or toasted nuts. I'm going to scatter on some
pecans.
Now roll up your dough.
Make a tight roll
and then work your way toward the edge.

When you're rolling your dough, your dough
might stick to the table so just make sure
you have a lot of flour.

Take your time as well. You don't need to
rush this part.
And there's your beautiful cinnamon rolls.

When you've rolled your dough, now it's time
to slice them.

So with a nice sharp, serrated knife, we are
going to cut two inches. Look at how beautiful that is.

That's all our hard work paying off right
there.

I love making these because they look so beautiful
even when they're raw.

Place your rolls in a deep baking tray lined
with parchment paper.

We're going to put a little bit of room in
between them because they're going to proof and grow.

but we do also want them to bake into each
other

because that's the beautiful style of batch
baking I really like.

Can you believe how gorgeous these look? I
can't wait to bake them off. They need one
more proof before they go in the oven
so we're going to cover them in cling film,

put a towel on them and let them rise a little
bit longer.

Our cinnamon rolls have been proofing for
half an hour, and they're actually ready.

They've kind of grown into each other and
that's exactly what we want.

Bake your cinnamon rolls at 375 degrees F
for 40-45 minutes or until golden brown.

While our cinnamon rolls are in the oven,
we're going to make the cream cheese glaze for the top.

In a bowl, add in your room temperature butter
and cream cheese.

And then mix them together with a whisk. Just
mix them until combined for around 3 minutes.
And then we're going to add in our icing sugar
and our vanilla extract.
And then mix until well combined.

We are rockin' this Bigger Bolder Baking episode
with no machines!

I think our cinnamon rolls are done so let's
check them out.

Now tell me they're not some of the most gorgeous
cinnamon rolls you ever saw.
Now look. Nice and bubbly.

I cut one of the rolls because I really want
you to see the benefits of the no-knead dough.

Do you see all these lovely air bubbles. And
texture, that's what the fermenting does.

These rolls are beautiful and brown on top
and they've got a gorgeous caramelized bottom
where all the filling sank and baked.

I am one step closer to eating these cinnamon
rolls

so while they're still warm, I'm going to
cover them in my cream cheese frosting.
Don't be afraid to lay the frosting on thick.
Look at that beautiful texture.

This cinnamon roll recipe is hands down my
favorite

and I have a feeling it's going to be yours
too.

Thanks so much for watching. And don't forget
to subscribe to my channel for more great

recipes like this one. I'll see you back here
again next Thursday for more Bigger Bolder Baking.

title: Best-Ever Cinnamon Rolls (Easy Recipe: No-Knead, No Machine) - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep. 34
